title: Tesco hits shoppers' wallets by changing click and collect charges
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 14, 2015, 02:10 BST - UK Markets open in 5 hrs 50 mins Tesco hits shoppers' wallets by changing click and collect charges By Andrew Trotman | Telegraph – 32 minutes ago 33.27 -0.32 
Shoppers who order items worth a total of less than £40 from Tesco's website and want to pick them in one of its stores will be forced to pay a £4 surcharge 
Tesco has become the latest retailer to hit shoppers' wallets by changing how much it charges online customers to pick up items in stores. 
The supermarket currently charges £4 for "click and collect" orders below £25. However, this threshold will rise to £40 from July 28. 
The move sparked anger among Tesco's customers. 
One shopper, Lisa Weston , wrote on Tesco's Facebook (NasdaqGS: FB - news ) page : "Why is Tesco minimum online basket changing from £25 to a massive £40? Think I need to change supermarkets." 
Keith King tweeted: "Click and collect minimum spend going up from £25 to £40 next week @Tesco no thank you. I'm off." 
Tesco did not immediately return calls for comment but told one customer on Twitter (Swiss: TWTR.SW - news ) : "We want to continue offering customers good deals for online, including £1 one-hour delivery slots and Click & Collect." 
Britain's biggest retailer offers free delivery when customers sign up to its Delivery Saver programme. However, this costs from £3 a month to £60 for a year, depending on when households want their items delivered. 
This method offers Tesco a more reliable revenue stream than customers ordering items online whenever they see goods they like. 
It is the latest blow for shoppers, after John Lewis announced plans earlier this month to start charging shoppers £2 to collect online orders in shops. It claims that web-based business models have become “unsustainable” and “bonkers”. 
From the end of this month, John Lewis will charge £2 for click-and-collect on orders of less than £30. Orders worth more than £30 will still be free to collect in John Lewis and Waitrose stores. 
Andy Street, managing director of John Lewis 
Andy Street, managing director of John Lewis, said the charge would account for roughly 18pc of the retailer’s orders. 
John Lewis made the announcement as Amazon revealed that it planned to deliver some online orders within an hour in London. Amazon Prime Now will allow shoppers to pay £6.99 to get 10,000 products, including everyday items such as coffee, within an hour of ordering. 
Some retailers already charge for click-and-collect, including Mike Ashley’s Sports Direct.
